MatchedObjectDescriptor.QualificationSummary:
**To meet the minimum qualification requirements for this position, you must show that you possess the five Executive Core Qualifications (ECQs), Technical Qualification(s), and other qualifications, if applicable (such as Education - see below). Additional information on ECQs is available at http://www.opm.gov/ses/recruitment/ecq.asp. (1) Mandatory Executive Core Qualification (MANDATORY SUBMISSION) (ECQ) All applicants must submit written statements (narrative format) describing accomplishments that would satisfy the ECQs. Use the Challenge-Context-Action-Result (CCAR) Model to describe your accomplishments. You must address each ECQ separately. You are required to respond to all ECQs. Failure to do so, will result in an 'ineligible' rating. Each accomplishment should be clear, concise, and emphasize your level of responsibilities, the scope and complexity of programs managed, and results of your actions. Total ECQ write-up should not exceed 10 pages using 12pt, Arial or Times New Roman with 1 inch margins. Please Note: Current career SES members, former career SES members with reinstatement eligibility, and SES Candidate Development Program (DCP), who have been certified by the OPM do not need to address ECQs, However when applying you must load your certificate under the Executive Core Qualifications. ECQ 1 - Leading Change: This core qualification involves the ability to bring about strategic change, both within and outside the organization, to meet organizational goals. Inherent to this ECQ is the ability to establish an organizational vision and to implement it in a continuously changing environment. ECQ 2 - Leading People: This core qualification involves the ability to lead people toward meeting the organization's vision, mission, and goals. Inherent to this ECQ is the ability to provide an inclusive workplace that fosters the development of others, facilitates cooperation and teamwork, and supports constructive resolution of conflicts. ECQ 3 - Results Driven: This core qualification involves the ability to meet organizational goals and customer expectations. Inherent to this ECQ isthe ability to make decisions that produce high-quality results by applying technical knowledge, analyzing problems, and calculating risks. ECQ 4 - Business Acumen: This core qualification involves the ability to manage human, financial, and information resources strategically. ECQ 5 - Building Coalitions: This core qualification involves the ability to build coalitions internally and with other Federal agencies, State and local governments, nonprofit and private sector organizations, foreign governments, or international organizations to achieve common goals. (2) MANDATORY TECHNICAL QUALIFICATION(S) (TQ): (MANDATORY SUBMISSION) A supplemental statement must be submitted separately addressing each TQ. Your TQ must provide specific examples that address relevant experience and accomplishments. Total TQ write-up should not exceed 2 pages per TQ using 12pt, Arial or Times New Roman with 1 inch margins. Applicants must reflect superior technical qualifications demonstrated through leadership and management in the following: MTQ 1: Demonstrated ability to manage the overall direction, program management and execution of the Division's Civil Works (Planning and Policy, Environmental Stewardship, Coastal Storm Damage Reduction, Flood Risk Management, Operations - Navigation, Hydropower, Recreation, Aquatic Ecosystem Restoration, Real Estate), Military Construction (Military Construction
(MILCON), Facilities Sustainment, Restoration, and Modernization (SRM), Hazardous, Toxic, Radiological Waste (HTRW) remediation, Real Estate), and Interagency Programs at distributed locations. MTQ 2: Ability to represents the Division as an authorized technical representative with other regional federal and non-federal entities within the Division boundaries. Ability to participate with the Division Commander on Congressional engagements and to establish working relationship with various functional chiefs, Congressional members and their staffs, other federal departments, and state and local government officials within the Division AOR.

Details.AgencyMarketingStatement: Civilian employees serve a vital role in supporting the Army mission. They provide the skills that are not readily available in the military, but crucial to support military operations. The Army integrates the talents and skills of its military and civilian members to form a Total Army. This position is in the Senior Executive Service (SES) which is a small elite group of top government leaders. SES members possess a diverse portfolio of experiences including strong skills to lead across organizations. As a Senior Executive, you will influence the direction of innovation and transformation of the federal government and lead the next generation of public servants. The Department of the Army is an Equal Opportunity Employer.
MajorDuties: Serves as the Division Programs Director, with responsibility and accountability for overall direction, staff management, and program management of the Division's Civil Works, Military Missions, and Interagency Support Programs. Responsible for development, defense, and execution of the Civil Works Program in the Southwestern Division region within six States to include Congressional and stakeholder engagement. Also responsible for executing the Military Missions within three States to include Army, Air Force, DOD Military Construction, Installation Support to military installations, Environmental Restoration and Hazardous & Toxic Radioactive Waste Remediation, and Interagency Support to other federal agencies. Programs and projects are funded through multiple sources to include Civil Works, DOD, Army, Air Force, other federal agencies, and local sponsors. Manages completion of multi-year programs, within appropriations and constraints to achieve targeted quality, budget and schedule requirements. This process requires integration and reconciliation of the perspectives of the Regional Business Directorate and other Division Headquarters elements to assure adherence to Department of the Army commitments made to Congress, Major Commands, installations, sponsors, and State and local government officials. Responsible for quality process management, technology transfer, and the maintenance and development of core competencies within the program/project management, environmental, civil works operations, regulatory permitting under the Clean Water Act, real estate, and planning technical functions. Directly supervises positions through the GS-15 level and indirectly supervises (provides staff supervision over) positions performing technical functions in subordinate districts. Under broad authority from the Division Commanding General, the Programs Director is steward for executive direction and management through four USACE Districts planning, operating, maintaining, and constructing infrastructure driven by requirements generated by non-federal water resource partners, military departments, and other federal agencies.

Details.AgencyMarketingStatement: The Office of General Counsel (OGC) is the exclusive NSA component responsible for providing legal services to all NSA elements. Details.JobSummary: The Defense Counterintelligence and Security Agency (DCSA) is a separate Agency of the Department of Defense (DoD) under the direction, authority, and control of the Under Secretary of Defense for Intelligence & Security (USD (I&S)). This is a Tier 3 position.
Details.AgencyMarketingStatement:
DCSA Mission Statement:
Through vetting, industry engagement, education, and counterintelligence and insider threat support, secure the trustworthiness of the United States Government's workforce, the integrity of its cleared contractor support, and the uncompromised nature of its technologies, services, and supply chains. . DCSA Vision Statement:
Optimize our performance as the preeminent security organization to protect our nation's critical assets through enterprise risk management, continuous innovation, and excellence in mission performance and customer service. http://www.dcsa.mil
MajorDuties: The incumbent serves as the Assistant Director for Personnel Security (PS). PS reduces risk posed by trusted insiders, promotes early detection of anomalies, and modernizes and aligns vetting programs to ensure a DoD workforce entrusted to protect U.S. Government information and property. Responsibilities include: Oversee the sustainment, transformation, and integration of DoD Personnel Security and Suitability, and Credentialing programs within DCSA, and the inculcation of new personnel security and related missions across the DCSA enterprise. Support the Director, DCSA, in modernizing how the U.S. Federal Government assesses personnel security by working in conjunction with DoD to support the design, development, security, and operation of technology focused personnel security systems and programs, including Background Investigations (BI), Adjudications (ADJ) and Vetting Risk Operations (VRO). Administer all BI, ADJ, and VRO operations and ensure that the subordinate directorates, along with other personnel security programs, execute requirements in accordance with appropriate laws, DoD regulations and policies. Direct BI, ADJ, and VRO operations with concern for pricing, product quality, timeliness, employee productivity, income/cost relationships, and alternative delivery strategies, including investments in information technology. Direct the development, coordination, technical guidance, and evaluation of necessary policy formulation; and responsible for program planning of DoD's Governmentwide personnel security programs for suitability, fitness, security, and credentialing determinations. Provide advice and support on the development and fielding of new information technology (IT) platforms focused on improving BI, ADJ, and VRO.

To meet the minimum qualification requirements for this position, you must show that you possess the five Executive Core Qualifications (ECQs), the Mandatory Technical Qualifications, and other qualifications, if applicable, listed below. EXECUTIVE CORE QUALIFICATIONS: All applicants must submit written statements (narrative format) describing accomplishments that would satisfy the ECQs. You must address each ECQ separately, not to exceed a total of 10 pages. You are required to respond to all ECQs. Failure to do so will result in a rating of 'ineligible.' When responding to the Executive Core Qualifications (ECQs), you must clearly show that you possess the experience, knowledge, skills and ability to perform the duties of this position by submitting narrative responses in which you detail your experience in each of the ECQs. Your examples should be clear and emphasize your level of responsibilities, scope and complexity of programs managed, program accomplishments with results of your actions, policy initiatives and level of contacts. You should limit your narrative to two pages per ECQ, and address each ECQ separately. OPM's Guide to Senior Executive Service Qualifications can assist you in writing an effective SES application. In particular, please note the Challenge-Context-Action-Result Model that is recommended and very helpful when drafting ECQ narrative responses. The Guide is available on OPM's Website at:
http://www.opm.gov/ses/references/guidetoSESQuals_2012.pdf Applicants must utilize the Challenge-Context-Action-Result (CCAR) Model when writing Executive Core Qualifications (ECQ). Use two examples of relevant experience for each ECQ being sure your experience matches the ECQ criteria. Challenge - Describe a specific problem or goal.
Context - Describe the individuals and groups you worked with, and/or the environment in which you worked, to address a particular challenge (e.g., clients, co-workers, members of Congress, shrinking budget, low morale).
Action - Discuss the specific actions you took to address a challenge.
Result - Give specific examples of measures/outcomes that had some impact on the organization. These accomplishments demonstrate the quality and effectiveness of your leadership skills. Each accomplishment should be clear, concise, and emphasize your level of responsibilities; the scope and complexity of the programs, activities, or services you managed; program accomplishments; policy initiatives undertaken; level of contacts; the sensitivity and criticality of the issues you addressed; and the results of your actions. You should use action oriented leadership words to describe your experience and accomplishments (e.g., Led the development and implementation of....) and quantify your experience wherever possible to demonstrate your accomplishments (e.g., number of employees supervised; size of budget managed; amount of money saved, etc.). ECQ 1 - Leading Change: This core qualification involves the ability to bring about strategic change, both within and outside the organization, to meet organizational goals. Inherent to this ECQ is the ability to establish an organizational vision and to implement it in a continuously changing environment. ECQ 2 - Leading People: This core qualification involves the ability to lead people toward meeting the organization's vision, mission, and goals. Inherent to this ECQ is the ability to provide an inclusive workplace that fosters the development of others, facilitates cooperation and teamwork, and supports constructive resolution of conflicts. ECQ 3 - Results Driven: This core qualification involves the ability to meet organizational goals and customer expectations. Inherent to this ECQ is the ability to make decisions that produce high-quality results by applying technical knowledge, analyzing problems, and calculating risks. ECQ 4 - Business Acumen: This core qualification involves the ability to manage human, financial, and information resources strategically. ECQ 5 - Building Coalitions: This core qualification involves the ability to build coalitions internally and with other Federal agencies, State and local governments, nonprofit and private sector organizations, foreign governments, or international organizations to achieve common goals. Applicants that are either Career SES members, or graduates of the Office of Personnel Management Certified Development Program are not required to address the ECQs. MANDATORY TECHNICAL QUALIFICATIONS: All applicants must submit written statements (narrative format) of accomplishments that would satisfy the technical qualifications. You must address each technical qualification separately. You are required to respond to all of the technical qualifications. If you fail to do so, you will be rated as ineligible. Please limit your written statements to no more than two pages per technical qualification. Comprehensive, professional knowledge of, and experience in, applying Federal statutes, regulations and case law in at least three of the following areas: civilian personnel, labor relations, and equal employment opportunity law; personnel security law; fiscal and appropriations law; federal procurement law; environmental law; information technology; the law of federal installations; standards of conduct; Federal Advisory Committee Act and Freedom of Information Act; criminal law, investigations, rules of engagement, use of force, search and seizure, First Amendment activities, insider threat, and rules of evidence in support of law enforcement and security; and administrative, real estate and real property management law. Demonstrated ability in effective and decisive decision-making, as well as the ability to solve problems of substantial impact, sensitivity, and complexity. Demonstrated ability in leading and managing a law office, legal office, or major legal division/department at the department/headquarters level.

Details.AgencyMarketingStatement: This position is in the Senior Executive Service (SES), a small, elite group of top government leaders. SES members possess a diverse portfolio of experiences including strong skills to lead across organizations. As a Senior Executive, you will influence the direction of innovation and transformation of the federal government and lead the next generation of public servants.
MajorDuties: The incumbent serves as a legal advisor to organizations reporting to the Director of Administration and Management (DA&M), including the Director, Washington Headquarters Services (WHS); Director, Pentagon Force Protection Agency (PFPA); and the WHS and PFPA office directors. The Deputy General Counsel, WHS and PFPA provides legal advice, counsel, and guidance on the full range of operations of client organizations. Legal areas of emphasis include, but are not limited to: criminal law enforcement, security, anti-terrorism and force protection; personnel and administration; fiscal law, standards of conduct and conflicts of interest; office renovation and major construction initiatives; procurement and contracts, to include contracts for services, design and construction, information technology, and interagency acquisitions. Major duties and responsibilities include, but are not limited to: Serves as a principal legal advisor and provides comprehensive legal advice to the Director, PFPA, and the Director, WHS and the office directors within each organization. Provides comprehensive legal advice to WHS leadership and other personnel, including in the areas of human resources, acquisition; facilities, executive and business services; financial management; boards, commissions, and tasks forces; the WHS security programs; the defense historical office; and the WHS Equal Employment Opportunity program. Provides comprehensive legal advice to PFPA leadership and officers, including in the areas of security, law enforcement, force protection, anti-terrorism, support for investigation and crimes and the execution of law enforcement, and threats to the Department of Defense operations in the National Capitol Region. Provides legal advice and guidance on a wide variety of sensitive matters for the senior officials of WHS, PFPA, and the Office of the Secretary of Defense (OSD); assists the General Counsel, WHS and PFPA, in overseeing WHS and PFPA participation in adversarial proceedings, including hearings before the Merit Systems Protection Board, Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, U.S. District Court (including Magistrate's Court), Government Accountability Office, Armed Services Board of Contract Appeals, and other fora; and oversees the prosecution of cases by WHS & PFPA OGC lawyers acting as Special Assistant United States Attorneys in the Eastern District of Virginia. Provides specialized legal support to certain classified programs and activities of OSD that require operational and administrative legal support as well as to certain classified security and force protection matters assigned to PFPA and WHS; and provides operational counsel in support of the OSD Continuity of Operations Program and Command, Control Survivability Program. Oversees the legal component of training to all PFPA officers in rules of engagement, use of force, search and seizure, First Amendment issues, and rules of Evidence in support of the law enforcement and security services on the Pentagon Reservation.

The Office of the Secretary of Defense (OSD) is the principal staff element of the Secretary of Defense in the exercise of policy development, planning, resource management, and program evaluation responsibilities. OSD includes the Offices of the Secretary and Deputy Secretary of Defense, Under Secretaries of Defense, Deputy Chief Management Officer, Assistant Secretaries of Defense, General Counsel, and the Director of Administration.
MajorDuties: The Principal Director, Civilian Personnel Policy (PD(CPP)) serves as a Deputy Chief Human Capital Officer (CHCO) for the Department on behalf of the DASD(CPP) who is delegated to act as the DoD CHCO on behalf of the USD(P&R). In this position, the incumbent advises and coordinates DoD's activities on such matters as the modernization of human resources systems, improved quality of HR information, and legislation affecting civilian HR operations and organizations at cabinet-interdepartmental planning and policy meetings. The PD(CPP) works closely with the Office of Personnel Management (OPM), the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), Congress, and the other 23 Executive Departments and Federal agencies. The PD(CPP)'s specific areas of responsibility include, but are not limited to: labor-management and employee relations; performance management; employment; classification, compensation; executive resource management; strategic human capital planning and evaluation; merit system principles; workforce and leadership development; workplace violence; work life programs; DoD's Non-Appropriated Fund personnel system; the development, integration, modernization, and sustainment of the civilian HR management information technology systems; the expeditionary civilian program; and benefits and entitlements. As Principal Director, the incumbent serves as the senior DoD subject matter expert in the above fields and directs senior staff in all assigned program areas. Subject to the authority, direction, and control of the DASD(CPP), the incumbent directs the development and implementation of policies, programs, and regulations for the entire lifecycle of civilian HR functional areas and provides the Director and Deputy Director, DCPAS policy direction. Formulates Department-wide Human Resource Management (HRM) strategic plans, programmatic objectives, policies, standards, directives, and instructions through a subordinate policy staff of civilian personnel experts and directs and provides oversight to the DCPAS Director and Deputy on the same. Supports the DASD(CPP) in oversight and enforcement of DoD civilian personnel management policies. The incumbent reviews and analyzes DoD components' personnel programs to promote economy, improvement, and consistency in the application of DoD civilian personnel management policies and programs. Advises and assists the DASD(CPP) in assigned responsibilities and functions, and provides support to the DoD Components in the administration of civilian personnel policy and programs, as directed. Investigates and evaluates new approaches and developments within the human resources management field and conducts studies leading to the application of these practices to DoD-wide civilian personnel policies and programs Participates in the coordination of the annual review of Component civilian employment targets and plans. Supervises the development of innovative alternatives and new solutions to civilian work force management problems. Supervises the preparation of issue papers and decision documents for use by the USD(P&R), ASD(M&RA), and DASD(CPP). Provides oversight to the development and evaluation of the various DoD personnel demonstration projects; policies and programs for the employment of U.S. citizens in foreign areas; and provides guidance to the DoD Per Diem Travel and Transportation Allowance Committee on civilian travel, per diem, and relocation allowances. Directs the administration of executive personnel matters for the Department, including the Senior Executive Service, Senior Professionals, Highly Qualified Experts, and equivalent positions under OPM approved demonstration projects. Represents DoD during interaction contacts with appropriate segments of the Legislative, Executive, and Judicial Branches of the Federal Government, professional, special interest and public citizens groups, and the media (in coordination with the Office of the Assistant Secretary of Defense ASD (Public Affairs) staff on civilian personnel matters. Represents the Department in meetings with senior officials of the DoD Components, the Office of Personnel Management, the Department of State, other Federal agencies, various national labor organizations, and Defense Department officials from other countries. Works with the Military Departments, Defense Agencies and Field Activities, members of Congress, Congressional staff members, high-level officials of Federal, state, and local government entities, and local and national officials of public service and other organizations interested in public personnel administration and human resources management.

MajorDuties: Serves as the Deputy Director of the Force Management (FM) Directorate (DAMO-FM), which includes the Army Force Management School (AFMS), and as the Director of the U.S. Army Force Management Support Agency (USAFMSA), a Field Operating Agency under the direction of the FM Directorate. Serves as the senior Department of the Army civilian advisor on FM programs, objectives, and functions, providing executive leadership, guidance, and coordination for formulation of Army and DoD policies, procedures, and objectives for all activities that are the responsibility of the FM directorate, including force analysis, accounting, documentation, stationing, and personnel education and qualification. Performs a unique function for all components of the Army that requires an ability to analyze and interpret strategic guidance, temper the needs of Headquarters, Department of the Army (HQDA) and the field commands with Army priorities, and judiciously apply constrained resources to determine and document minimum mission essential wartime requirements and authorizations for manpower and equipment in Army Table of Organization and Equipment (TOE), Modified Table of Organization and Equipment (MTOE), Table of Distribution and Allowances (TDA), and Basis of Issue Plan (BOIP) documents. Serves as the Army authoritative source and is responsible for the complete and accurate documentation of requirements for all Army units/organizations and Army elements of joint organizations, across all Army components. Responsible for articulating HQDA force analysis recommendations affecting Army Commands, Army Service Component Commands, Direct Reporting Units, and Field Operating Agencies, through demonstrated understanding of Army resources, priorities, and risk, to support the development of force composition and resourcing. Serves as the senior technical advisor for all aspects of force management documentation to the Director, FM and Army G-3/5/7. Exercises full management responsibilities for all personnel assigned to DAMO-FM, USAFMSA, and AFMS, as well as contracted analytical, training, and information systems support. Works under the general direction of the Director, Force Management, who provides general policy guidance and broad objectives to be achieved. Shares fully in discharging all responsibilities for planning, directing, coordinating, reporting, evaluating, and controlling the work and associated resources involved in providing timely force management decisions for the Army. Exercises full management responsibility for assigned programs, functions, and objectives. Plans, directs the execution of, and controls accomplishment of all phases of force analysis, accounting, and documentation through subordinate division and support agency chiefs. Provides authoritative direction and guidance which influences the organization, direction, and control of resources required to achieve defined command objectives, and assures that force management programs are fully coordinated and effectively implemented. Ensures continuity and uniformity in the execution of all force management activities and is responsible for reviewing and approving actions of subordinate division and support agency chiefs on behalf of the Director of Force Management.
